content: {{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-242-01-A |Item_parent=Hyperthyroidism |Item_parent_short=Hyperthyroidism |Rank=A |Title=Know the definition of hyperthyroidism and thyrotoxicosis |Description=None |Rubric=Definition |Contributors=Dr Camille Buffet,Dr Magalie Haissaguerre |Order=1}} Hyperthyroidism = excess production of thyroid hormones linked to hyperfunction of the thyroid gland. Thyrotoxicosis = consequences of excess thyroid hormones in target tissues, whatever the cause: * release of thyroid hormones, as in De Quervain's sub-acute thyroiditis, for example * hyperproduction of thyroid hormones by the thyroid gland, as in Graves' disease, for example * exogenous supply of thyroid hormones (factitious thyrotoxicosis).

question.title: What is the definition of thyrotoxicosis?
question.description: The consequences of excess thyroid hormones in target tissues, whatever the cause.

option_a.title: Excess production of thyroid hormones linked to hyperfunction of the thyroid gland.
option_a.description: A condition characterized by an overproduction of thyroid hormones by the thyroid gland.

option_b.title: Release of thyroid hormones due to injury or infection.
option_b.description: A consequence of thyroid hormone release, as in De Quervain's sub-acute thyroiditis.

option_c.title: Exogenous supply of thyroid hormones from external sources.
option_c.description: A cause of thyrotoxicosis, such as factitious thyrotoxicosis.

option_d.title: A combination of all the above options.
